An amendment threatens probation reform.
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

In recent months, we've been talking a lot about probation reform in Pennsylvania. Probation is one of the most significant drivers of incarceration across the commonwealth, so reforming this broken system will be a huge step forward to addressing the state's mass incarceration crisis.

With legislation moving through both the Pennsylvania House and Senate, there is clear bipartisan support for reform.

But a proposed amendment threatens to undo everything we've worked for.

On Monday, the House Judiciary Committee will consider an amendment that, if passed, could gut the most meaningful aspects of probation reform and actually make Pennsylvania's probation system even worse that it currently is.

The amendment would weaken probation reform in several ways. It would strip away limits on the amount of time a person can be sentenced to probation. It would allow probation officers to conduct searches without having reasonable suspicion. It would create a number of exceptions to early termination of probation for good behavior, and more.

The bottom line? If this amendment passes, meaningful probation reform is in real danger.

Will you take a moment to leave a message for your state representative, who is a member of the House Judiciary Committee, and urge them to vote "No" on this amendment?

If lawmakers hear from enough constituents, we can defeat this amendment and save probation reform in the commonwealth.

Thank you for taking action for smart justice,

Elizabeth Randol
Legislative Director, ACLU of Pennsylvania
